facts.text: Explosions occurred on 16 March 1993 just before midnight in B.B. Ganguly Street, Bow Bazar Area of Calcutta, resulting in total demolition of building 267 and partial demolition of adjacent buildings 266 and 268.

anchor.surface_text: On 16th March, 1993, just before the stroke of mid-night, people in and around B.B. Ganguly Street in the Bow Bazar Area of Calcutta heard deafening sounds emanating from thundering explosions which resulted in total demolition of a building and partial demolition of two other adjacent buildings situated at 267,266 and 268 A, B.B. Ganguly Street.

facts.text: Large number of people died due to the explosions and falling debris on 16 March 1993, with 69 persons losing their lives.

anchor.surface_text: Large number of people were trapped in and buried under the demolished buildings. It was indeed a very ghastly sight and large number of people died because of the explosions impact and or on account of the falling debris.

facts.text: First Information Report was lodged at Bow Bazar Police Station for offences under Sections 120B, 436, 302, 307, 326 IPC and Sections 3 and 5 of Explosive Substances Act, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: The first information report was lodged at Bow Bazar Police Station for alleged commission of offences punishable under Section 120B, 436, 302, 307 326 of the Indian penal Code, I860  in short the IPC  and Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Substances Act, 1908  in short The Explosive Act .

facts.text: Commissioner of Police set up a special investigating team due to the seriousness of the incident.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the seriousness and gravity of the incident, the Commissioner of Police set up a special investigating team.

facts.text: Further explosion occurred on 18 March 1993 during rescue operations.

anchor.surface_text: While rescue operations were on there was further explosion on 18.3.1993.

facts.text: A gunny bag containing 22 live bombs was recovered by pay loader and defused.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the pay loader picked up a gunny bag containing 22 live bombs. Afterwards. They were defused after examination.

facts.text: Nitro-glycerin explosives were found involved in the explosion upon examination of seized materials.

anchor.surface_text: Certain materials were seized by the investigating team from the site of the occurrence and on examination, it was found that nitro-glycerin explosives were involved in the explosion.

facts.text: Pannalal Jayasora was arrested on 29 March 1993.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the accused persons, Pannalal Jaysoara  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 299/2002  and Mohd. Gulzar  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 494/2002  were arrested on 29.3.1993 and 13.5.1993 respectively.

facts.text: Mohd. Gulzar was arrested on 13 May 1993.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the accused persons, Pannalal Jaysoara  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 299/2002  and Mohd. Gulzar  accused-appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 494/2002  were arrested on 29.3.1993 and 13.5.1993 respectively.

facts.text: Confessional statements of Pannalal Jayasora and Mohd. Gulzar were recorded by Judicial Magistrates PW81 and PW82.

anchor.surface_text: As they wanted to make their confessions, those were to be recorded before the Judicial Magistrate, accordingly, their confessional statements were recorded by the magistrates  PWs.81 and 82 .

facts.text: Some accused persons were identified by witnesses in Test Identification Parade.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the accused persons were also identified by witnesses in the Test Identification Parade.

facts.text: On 11 June 1993, Commissioner of Police concluded TADA provisions applicable and sanction was accorded.

anchor.surface_text: On 11.6.1993. the Commissioner of Police on examination of the case diary, statement of witnesses, reports of the experts and confessional statements came to the conclusion that provisions of Terrorist and Disruptive Activities  Prevention  Act, 1987  in short The TADA Act  were applicable.

facts.text: Charge sheet submitted on 14 June 1993.

anchor.surface_text: Charge sheet was submitted on 14.6.1993.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court quashed the sanction and cognizance order under TADA, later reversed by Supreme Court in State of West Bengal v. Mohd. Khalid (1995 1 SCC 684).

anchor.surface_text: Accused Persons filed a writ application before the Calcutta High Court challenging the validity of the sanction and the order whereby the Designated Court took cognizance of the offences under the TADA Act. The High Court quashed the order of sanction and taking of cognizance.

facts.text: Designated Court framed charges under Sections 120B, 436/34, 302/34 IPC, Sections 3&5 Explosive Act, and TADA Sections 3(2)(i) and 3(3).

anchor.surface_text: The Designated Court framed charges under Section 120B, 436/34, 302/34, IPC, Section 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and under Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act.

facts.text: Prosecution case: Accused conspired to manufacture bombs using explosives to strike terror in Bow Bazar area and affect communal harmony between Hindus and Muslims.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution, in short, is that the accused persons conspired and agreed to manufacture bombs illegally by using explosives to strike terror in the people, particularly, in the mind of the people living in Bow Bazar and its adjacent areas to adversely affect communal harmony amongst members of Hindu and Muslim communities

facts.text: Terrorist acts resulted in death of 69 persons, injuries to many, and property damage.

anchor.surface_text: Their terrorist activities resulted in the death of 69 persons, injuries to a large number of persons and destruction and damage to properties.

facts.text: 165 witnesses examined, including star witnesses PW40 Md. Sabir Natu, PW67 Santosh Hazra, PW68 Kristin Chow Kittu.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the 165 witnesses examined, three witnesses were picked up as star witnesses to prove the conspiracy and the connected acts. They are PW. 40  Md. Sabir Natu , PW. 67  Santosh Hazra  and PW 68  Kristin Chow Kittu ,

facts.text: Designated Court convicted accused under Section 120B IPC, Sections 3&5 Explosive Act, TADA 3(2)(i) and 3(3) r/w 34 IPC; acquitted under 302/34 and 436/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: By a detailed judgment ,the Designated Court found the accused appellants guilty of offences punishable under Section 120 B IPC, Sections 3 and 5 of the Explosive Act and Section 3  2   1  and 3  3  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC. However, they were found not guilty of the offences in terms of Sections 302 and 436 read with Section 34 IPC.

facts.text: Accused sentenced to life imprisonment for TADA 3(2)(i) r/w 34 IPC, and other sentences for remaining offences.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing on the question of sentence, the accused appellants were sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for life and to pay a fine of Rs. 3000 each for commission of offences under Section 3  2   1  of the TADA Act read with Section 34 IPC, to undergo rigorous imprisonment for five years and to pay a fine of Rs. 500 each for commission of offence under Section 3  3  of the TADA Act.

facts.text: Accused appellants claimed star witnesses PW40,67,68 have doubtful antecedents and deposed falsely at police behest.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the accused appellants have submitted, inter alia, that the so- called star witnesses are persons with doubtful antecedents. They were rowdy elements who were under the thumb of police officers and the possibility of their having deposed falsely at the behest of police officers cannot be ruled out,

facts.text: Accused claimed confessions were retracted on 3 February 1995 due to terrorization and compulsion.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, no importance can be attached to the so-called judicial confessions because two accused person who allegedly made the confession had made retraction subsequently on 3.2.1995. They were terrorized, threatened and were compelled to make the confession.

facts.text: Accused claimed they were preparing bombs for self-protection in anticipation of Hindu attack, referencing Bombay riots.

anchor.surface_text: Even if, according to them, the prosecution case is accepted in its toto, it only proves that the Muslims were trying to protect themselves in the event of a possible attack of Hindus on them. In the bomb blast which took place in Bombay a few months earlier,

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld convictions under TADA, Explosive Act, and 120B IPC; dismissed accused appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals filed by the accused persons deserves to be dismissed, and we so direct.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld acquittal under 302/34 and 436/34 IPC; dismissed state appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals filed by the accused persons deserves to be dismissed, and we so direct. Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified. Though, it was submitted by Mr. K.T.S. Tulsi that higher sentences would have been more appropriate in respect of established offences, we do not think it necessary to go into that question in absence of an appeal by the prosecution in that regard. The appeal filed by the State is accordingly dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: All seven appeals (six by accused-appellants against conviction/sentence and one by State against acquittal) dismissed. Convictions and life sentences under Section 120B IPC, Sections 3(2)(i), 3(3) TADA, Sections 3,5 Explosive Act upheld. Acquittals under Sections 302/34, 436/34 IPC upheld. No enhancement of sentence.
directions: Trial courts must examine available witnesses without unnecessary adjournments; cross-examination should not be deferred unless compelling reasons; advocates must not seek adjournments cavalierly when witnesses are present.

In the background of what we have said about terrorists acts supra , plea of accused-appellants is clearly unacceptable. As was observed by this Court when earlier the matter was before it in the prosecutions appeal

The appeals filed by the accused persons deserves to be dismissed, and we so direct. Coming to the appeal filed by the prosecution against the acquittal in respect of charges under Section 302/34 and Section 436/34 IPC, learned counsel for the prosecution fairly stated, and in our opinion rightly, that the acquittal is justified. Though, it was submitted by Mr. K.T.S. Tulsi that higher sentences would have been more appropriate in respect of established offences, we do not think it necessary to go into that question in absence of an appeal by the prosecution in that regard. The appeal filed by the State is accordingly dismissed.
